commit_list.message: Fix typo and wording

Add support for count in srandmember

The `count` argument was present but not used in the `srandmember`
method.

This change adds support for the `count` argument based on the
specification of `srandmember` as described on:

http://redis.io/commands/srandmember

We can't use result checking between MockRedis and Redis in the specs
because `srandmember` gives random members so we'll likely get
different results between MockRedis and Redis.

Change-Id: I639cd5ff36b3e4b1b5a5c80a50e1c261ba131b0b
Reviewed-on: https://gerrit.causes.com/33202
Reviewed-by: Shane da Silva <shane@causes.com>
Tested-by: Shane da Silva <shane@causes.com>

commit_list.message:
don't raise a KeyError on unknown command

Currently, when you type an unknown subcommand (for example a typo), you hit a runtime error `missing hash key: "unknown_command" (KeyError)`. 
This change catches this and displays the help instead.

commit_list.message:
added a method_missing to catch newly created role outside the current ruby process (i.e. dynamic shortcut methods are not defined within this process)
dynamic shortcut is created on the fly in the method_missing to avoid extra method_missing for the same dynamic shortcut
check if the role actually exists in the database before defining the new method
first call is slower due to method_missing but next calls are fast
fixes #7

commit_list.message:
added has_all_roles? and has_any_roles? implementation
not very pleased of has_all_roles at the moment, one SQL query per requested role is too much for me.
has_any_role? is fine because a simple OR query works in that case (or a subselect with IN clause would have done the trick as well)

closes #2
commit_list.repo_description: Role management library with resource scoping

commit_list.message:
added some specs about #2
syntax for multiple roles checking :
user.has_all_roles? "admin", { :name => "moderator", :resource => Forum.first } will return true if user has ALL roles
user.has_any_roles? "admin", { :name => "moderator", :resource => Forum.first } will return true if user has ANY role

- has_role?(name, resource = nil) : get a role for the user, global if resource is nil, scoped otherwise
